 This is multiply wrong.
 
 First, I hope you actually mean "belief", "opinion" and "faith" to refer only to the issue of existence of a supreme being. Of course, both atheists and agnostics can have all 3 of those in other issues, including issues that are religious in essence.
 
 Second, while I respect the choice of individuals who call themselves agnostic, I do not know of any consistent definition of agnosticism that is not a subset of atheism. Of course, there are atheists who are not agnostics, i.e., who claim to actually know that there is no god. But I don't see how one can be an agnostic and at the same time not an atheist. That is logically inconsistent.
 
 Third, if there is such thing as agnosticism that is not atheism, it must by definition involve some degree of belief or faith; if it did not, it would be atheism. Now I am not sure what you mean by "opinion" in this context. Perhaps that an agnostic is one who simply has no opinion on matters of belief in god(s)? Well, that is not the standard definition (according to which an agnostic is one who disclaims any knowledge regarding the existence of god(s)), but it may be a pretty accurate description of the practical criterion people use to classify themselves.
 
 
for athiesm is the belief that god will never be proven to exist, and we don't know that. 

 
 Now this is a wrong definition I have not seen before. I have often heard that an atheist is one who positively claims that God does not exist (roughly the "atheist who is not agnostic" subset I described above). That is wrong, but it is at least a fairly standard definition of "strong atheism" or (more properly) "antitheism". Your definition is also wrong, but it is also quite interesting.
 
 The missing piece is the definition of "god" that atheists allegedly claim will never be proven to exist.
 
 If it is any particular god defined fairly precisely by the dogmas of a particular religion, then I would be perfectly comfortable saying not only that he will never be proven to exist, but also that I can easily prove that such an entity in fact does not exist.
 
 But if it is just some undefined supreme being, or even the very vaguely defined God of the more liberal Christian denominations and Reformed Judaism, then I would not make any statemens about the prospects of a proof or disproof of His existence; any such statement would be meaningless.

 Much of the debate centers around the definition of the word "marriage" Many people use the "traditional" (ie.: religious) definition. Different religions / religious sects withing the same religion interpret the word "marriage" differently. Merely as examples: Southern Baptist may define it as the union between one man and one woman; certain sects of Islam may define it as a union between one man and an indefinate number of women; the Metropolitan Community Church (a Christian denomination) may define it as the union of any two individuals. Please keep in mind that these are "religious" interpretations of the word "marriage".
 
 One of the cornerstones of the Constitution of the United States of America is freedom of religion and the government's non-imposition of religion. Can we agree on that? If so, feel free to parctice whichever religion you see fit and consider your "marriage" under whichever interpretation your choice of religion wishes. If you chose the "one man, one woman" religion, so be it. You are free to do so. If you chose the "one man, indefinate number of women" religion, so be it. If you chose the "union of any two individuals" religion, so be it. Your "marriage" will be duly recognized by your particular religion. Or you may chose to not have any religious interpretation at all. So be it. Let us leave the word "marriage" as a religious term.
 
 Another cornerstone of the Constitution of the United States of America is equal rights and equal protection under the law for all individuals.
 
 So, here's my proposition:LET'S DO BOTH!!!!!!! Let's preserve religious freedom AND civil rights.
 
 How do we do that? Quite simply: get government out of religion. Instead of passing a constitutional ammendment (as currently proposed) to specifically deny civil rights to a particular group of individuals ( can you imagine that!?!?!?!?! A fundamental change to the constitutional to deny civil rights?? Our founding fathers must be rolling in their graves!!! ). Instead, lets ammend all current federal law to remove any reference to the words "marriage", "marry" or any derivation thereof and replace it with "civil union" or a derivation thereof. 
 
 The result? Every individual has equal freedom of religion and every individual has equal civil rights. There is no fundamental change to the constitution, merely a clarification of terms. It is a "win-win" situation with no one losing anything!!!!!

TORONTO - Canada's highest court said today the government can redefine marriage to include same-sex couples, but it added that religious officials cannot be forced to perform unions against their beliefs.
 
 The ruling by the court in Ottawa brings to the final stages a long, bitter fight over whether gays and lesbians should be allowed to marry in Canada. 
 
 Judges in six provinces and one territory have already overturned the traditional definition, allowing thousands of same-sex weddings. 
 
 Canada would join Belgium and the Netherlands in allowing gay marriage if the government acts to make it legal nationwide. To pass in the House of Commons, the legislation needs the approval of about 44 of the 95 Liberal backbench members of Parliament to obtain a 155-vote majority. 
 
 One top Liberal predicted the legislation should pass easily after its introduction, likely early next year. It already has the support of the 38-member Liberal cabinet and virtually all the 54 Bloc Quebecois and 19 New Democrat MPs.

 The ruling by the court in Ottawa brings to the final stages a long, bitter fight over whether gays and lesbians should be allowed to marry in Canada. 
 
 Judges in six provinces and one territory have already overturned the traditional definition, allowing thousands of same-sex weddings. 
 
 Canada would join Belgium and the Netherlands in allowing gay marriage if the government acts to make it legal nationwide. To pass in the House of Commons, the legislation needs the approval of about 44 of the 95 Liberal backbench members of Parliament to obtain a 155-vote majority.

 "A Globe survey of the largest communities in Massachusetts shows that in some cities and towns same-sex couples have sought licenses in numbers that far exceed their proportion of the overall population.
 
 In Boston, gay or lesbian couples made up 491 of the 2,365 couples who have applied for licenses since May 17, or 21 percent of the total. Although exact numbers are hard to come by, the percentage of gay and lesbian adults in Boston is probably no more than 10 percent, according to Gary J. Gates, a demographer at the Urban Institute in Washington, D.C., and the author of the "Gay and Lesbian Atlas."
 
 Some Boston marriages probably involve people coming to the city because it offered an accepting environment. Gates said the relatively high number of gay and lesbian couples getting married probably reflects pent-up demand.
 
 "You have to remember that same-sex couples haven't had the ability to marry, so you would expect a surge that probably would not be sustained over time as it becomes a much more normalized process," Gates said.
 
 In Provincetown and Northampton, same-sex couples made up the majority of people who received marriage licenses in the last six months.
 
 In Provincetown, 912, or 97 percent, of the 937 couples who have applied for licenses since May 17 are same-sex couples. In Northampton, 325, or 66 percent, of the 494 couples who got licenses were gay or lesbian.
 
 In Provincetown, 225 of the same-sex couples applied for licenses during the first week after May 17, and in Northampton 114 did.
